title: 115_hr5906
content: The Act may be cited as the "ARPA-E Act of 2018" and establishes the Advanced Research Projects Agency-Energy. The America COMPETES Act is amended to focus on developing transformative science and technology solutions for energy, environmental, economic, and national security challenges. The goals include enhancing economic and energy security by reducing imports, emissions, and improving energy efficiency across all sectors. The America COMPETES Act is amended to focus on developing transformative solutions for energy, environmental, economic, and national security challenges. This includes improving the management, clean-up, and disposal of radioactive waste, enhancing energy production efficiency, and addressing challenges within the Department's mission as determined by the Secretary. The America COMPETES Act is amended to focus on developing transformative solutions for energy, environmental, economic, and national security challenges. This includes improving the management, clean-up, and disposal of radioactive waste, enhancing energy production efficiency, and addressing challenges within the Department's mission as determined by the Secretary. The amendments involve changing terminology from "energy technology projects" to "advanced technology projects," removing references to "energy" in certain sections, and requiring a strategic vision roadmap for future technology investments by ARPA-E. Coordination and nonduplication efforts are also emphasized. The ARPA-E Act of 2018 emphasizes coordination with existing programs, avoiding duplication of efforts, and requiring private financing attempts for projects. Additionally, the Secretary is authorized to enter into a contract with the National Academy for evaluation purposes. The ARPA-E Act of 2018 authorizes the Secretary to contract the National Academy for evaluation. Protection of proprietary information is also addressed in the Act. Information collected by ARPA-E from award recipients is considered privileged and confidential, not subject to disclosure. This includes plans for commercializing technologies, third-party investments, and additional financial support the awardee plans to invest or has invested. The awardee's plans to invest in technology developed under the award or seek third-party investments, as well as revenue from new products or services resulting from research, are protected information. Section 5012 of the Act is amended by removing a specific time period, and there are technical amendments made to subsections (g)(3)(A)(iii) and (o)(2). The House of Representatives passed the legislation on June 27, 2018. Karen L. Haas is the Clerk.
